Dear Ms. Marry:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 12/10/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517- 243- 9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation
• (1) An agency shall recommend to the
department the appropriate licensing action
consistent with facts contained in the foster
home evaluation and any special evaluations.
One of two foster home special evaluations reviewed did not report the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts to the department timely.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting
the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency
shall give a copy to and review the parent-
agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan

and any other information about the child and
the child's family is confidential.
Two of six foster care case records reviewed did not have documentation that
indicated a copy was provided to the parents/foster parents.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/18/23
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of two adoptive family evaluations were not completed within 90 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP Approved 12/18/23

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: Interim
report completed on 11/27/23 and CAP approved on 12/18/2023. The agency
was cited with four violations. The agency is in non-compliance with two of those
violations during this reporting period. More focus is needed to bring these two
violations into compliance.
Special investigation #2024SIC0001302, initiated 4/2/2024 was found in non-
compliance with Rules 400.12207 Staff responsibilities, 400.12314 Religion and
spirituality policy and 400.12418 (1) Development of service plans. The report
was completed on 7/24/2024 and the CAP was approved on 10/15/24. The
agency is still working on their CAP, however, during this reporting period there
has been no repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
The Chief Administrator (CA) reported barriers/systemic factors related to
achieving compliance regarding the areas of non-compliance focusing on foster
care. She reported there are large amount of policy items required for a foster
care case. She reported workers reported finding it difficult to prioritize paperwork
completion during times that they have a crisis on their caseload, as the crisis
takes precedent. She said there are also times when cases are more complex,
have more frequent court hearings or requirements, which all take precedent over
the documentation portion of a foster care case. The CA reported as an agency
they had previously set aside protected time to address concerns related to social
work contact documentation. CA reported recently, time has been extended, from
two hours to six hours, in order to include time to work on documentation of the
case throughout MiSACWIS, in addition to social work contacts being added.
Financial Overview:
The agency submitted their agency budget and independent audit dated
9/30/2023. No concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews:
Three staff members were interviewed onsite 11/21/24. The staff interviewed
reported they feel very supported and work as a team. The training is excellent,
and the staff reported they really enjoy the environment. Staff reported the agency
allows the workers to work mobile as much as possible and the agency has

recently started a bounce incentive program that provides recognition to the
employees.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
There is sufficient space for staff and clients. There is adequate locking storage for
confidential information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified two safety concerns:
Safety Alert: The foster home was missing a smoke alarm between the foster
child’s bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution: A special investigation 2025SEC0000125 was initiated on 11/12/2024
on the foster home. The foster family installed a smoke detector immediately
outside of the identified bedroom. The smoke detector was observed to be installed
and operational as observed by the licensing worker. Photo of the smoke detector
is attached to the safety alert.
Safety Alert: A smoke detector was not able to be verified in the basement during
the home visit.
Resolution: A smoke detector was verified to be in the basement and in working
order.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
